text: I'm throwing everything against the wall. I'm looking at what's going to stick. I am looking to try to find the winning tactic and turn it into a winning strategy.
speaker: Marc Benioff
context: Lenny asks Marc about lessons from Salesforce's legendary launch event where they hired fake protesters outside a competitor's conference. Marc explains his approach to marketing and product launches, emphasizing the importance of experimentation. He describes how he tests multiple approaches simultaneously to discover what resonates with customers before committing resources to scale the most effective tactics into comprehensive strategies.
text_ko: 일단 닥치는 대로 다 해보고 있어요. 뭐가 먹히는지 보고, 먹히는 전술(tactic)을 찾아 그걸 효과적인 전략(strategy)으로 만들려고 해요.
text_zh: 我现在什么方法都在试，看看哪个能行。我要找到那个管用的打法，然后把它变成制胜策略。
text_es: Estoy probando de todo a ver qué funciona. Quiero ver qué da resultado. Busco encontrar la táctica ganadora y convertirla en una estrategia exitosa.
key_sentence: I'm throwing everything against the wall to find the winning tactic.

text: I actually never look at the stock. I find the stock to be very distracting. The stock isn't the goal. That's not why we're doing this.
speaker: Marc Benioff
context: When Lenny mentions that Salesforce's stock is at an all-time high and asks what contributed to their continued growth, Marc reveals his philosophy about focusing on the business rather than financial metrics. He explains that he deliberately avoids monitoring stock prices because he believes the stock price should be a byproduct of building a great company, not the primary objective that drives decision-making.
text_ko: 사실 저는 주식(stock)을 아예 안 봐요. 주식은 오히려 산만해서 집중을 흐트러뜨려요. 주식 자체가 목표가 아니에요. 우리가 이걸 하는 이유가 그게 아니거든요.
text_zh: 其实我从来不看股价。我觉得股价特别容易让人分心。股价不是我们的目标，我们做这个事儿也不是为了股价。
text_es: La verdad es que nunca me fijo en las acciones. Me parece que las acciones te distraen mucho. Las acciones no son el objetivo. No es por eso que estamos haciendo esto.
key_sentence: The stock isn't the goal; it's very distracting.

text: No, no, no, no, no. That's a mistake. You want the mindset of, 'Oh, the next thing is coming. I can't wait for the next thing.'
speaker: Marc Benioff
context: Lenny expresses frustration about how founders struggle to keep up with rapid technological changes, saying they just got used to AI and now have to figure out agents. Marc strongly disagrees with this mindset, arguing that successful entrepreneurs should be excited about constant innovation rather than overwhelmed by it. He believes embracing continuous change and looking forward to new technological developments is essential for long-term success.
text_ko: 아니요, 아니요, 아니요, 아니요, 아니요. 그건 잘못된 생각이에요. 원하시는 건 "아, 다음 일이 곧 올 거야. 다음 게 너무 기대돼서 기다릴 수가 없어"라는 마인드셋(mindset)이에요.
text_zh: 不不不，这样想就错了。你要有这种心态：'哎呀，下一个机会要来了，我都等不及了。'
text_es: No, no, no, no, no. Eso es un error. Lo que necesitas es la mentalidad de "Ay, ya viene lo siguiente. No puedo esperar a ver qué sigue."
key_sentence: Embrace the mindset of 'I can't wait for' the next thing.

text: In the beginner's mind, I have every possibility, but in the expert's mind, I have few, and in some cases, maybe none. So I've been doing this a long time. I've been writing software since I'm 15. I'm now 60. That's 45 years. I don't want to have an expert's mind. I want to have a beginner's mind.
speaker: Marc Benioff
context: Marc discusses the importance of maintaining a beginner's mind even after decades of experience. He explains this concept from Zen Buddhism called 'Shoshin' - the idea that approaching situations with an open, eager attitude free from preconceptions leads to more creative solutions. Despite 45 years in software development, he actively cultivates this mindset through meditation and deliberately avoiding the trap of thinking he knows all the answers.
text_ko: 초심자 마음(beginner's mind)일 때는 모든 가능성이 열려 있어요. 하지만 전문가의 마음(expert's mind)으로는 가능성이 훨씬 줄고, 어떤 경우에는 아예 없을 수도 있어요. 저는 이 일을 오래 해왔어요. 15살 때부터 소프트웨어(software)를 개발해왔고, 지금은 60살이에요. 그러니까 45년이나 됐죠. 그래서 전문가의 마음을 갖고 싶지 않아요. 계속 초심자 마음을 유지하고 싶어요.
text_zh: 初学者的心态里，什么都有可能，但专家的心态里，可能性就很少了，有时候甚至完全没有。我做这行已经很久了，从15岁就开始写代码，现在60岁了，整整45年。我不想有专家心态，我要保持初学者心态。
text_es: Con la mentalidad de principiante, tengo todas las posibilidades del mundo, pero con la mentalidad de experto, tengo pocas, y en algunos casos, tal vez ninguna. Mira, llevo mucho tiempo en esto. He estado programando desde los 15 años. Ahora tengo 60. Son 45 años. No quiero tener mentalidad de experto. Quiero mantener la mentalidad de principiante.
key_sentence: A beginner's mind offers every possibility, unlike an expert's mind.

text: I am looking to try to find the winning tactic and turn it into a winning strategy. I don't know actually which one of those things is going to be the most important thing in launching this product, so I'm trying a lot of things with that old expression. I'm throwing everything against the wall. I'm looking at what's going to stick.
speaker: Marc Benioff
context: Marc explains his current approach to launching Agentforce, Salesforce's new AI agent product. He describes running multiple parallel experiments including celebrity endorsements with Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson, aggressive marketing against Microsoft's Copilot, and hiring additional salespeople. His philosophy is to test many different tactics simultaneously rather than betting everything on one approach, then scale whichever proves most effective.
text_ko: 효과 있는 전술(winning tactic)을 찾아서 그걸 효과적인 전략(winning strategy)으로 만들려고 해요. 사실 어떤 게 이 제품 출시에서 가장 중요할지 모르겠어서, 옛말처럼 이것저것 많이 시도해 보고 있어요. 가능한 건 다 해봐서 뭐가 통하는지 보고 있어요.
text_zh: 我想找到那个制胜的策略，把它变成一套完整的打法。说实话，我也不知道在推这个产品的时候哪个点最关键，所以我就多试试呗，就是那句老话说的——广撒网，看看哪个能行得通。
text_es: Estoy buscando encontrar la táctica que funcione y convertirla en una estrategia ganadora. La verdad es que no sé cuál de todas estas cosas va a ser lo más importante para lanzar este producto, así que estoy probando muchas cosas con esa filosofía de siempre. Estoy echando toda la carne al asador. Quiero ver qué es lo que va a cuajar.
key_sentence: I'm throwing everything against the wall to find the winning tactic.

text: It's not just about the product. It's not just about sales. It's not just about marketing. It's about everything, so you better be ready to be an orchestra leader. You can't just be playing the clarinet.
speaker: Marc Benioff
context: Lenny asks about advice for product-oriented founders who are hesitant to focus on sales and marketing. Marc responds by rejecting the idea that companies should be narrowly focused on just one area like product development. He uses the metaphor of an orchestra to explain that successful entrepreneurs must coordinate all aspects of their business - product, sales, marketing, finance, employees, and stakeholders - rather than excelling in just one area.
text_ko: 제품만으로 되는 게 아니에요. 영업만으로 되는 것도 아니고, 마케팅만으로 되는 것도 아니에요. 결국 모든 걸 아우르는 일이어서 오케스트라 지휘자(orchestra leader)처럼 전체를 지휘할 준비가 돼 있어야 해요. 클라리넷만 불고 있으면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 这不只是产品的事儿，也不只是销售的事儿，更不只是市场营销的事儿。这是个全方位的活儿，所以你得准备好当个乐队指挥。你不能只会吹单簧管就完事了。
text_es: No es solo el producto. No es solo las ventas. No es solo el marketing. Es todo junto, así que más te vale estar listo para ser director de orquesta. No puedes quedarte solo tocando el clarinete.
key_sentence: Be an orchestra leader, not just playing the clarinet.

text: My friend, Michael Bell, is probably the best entrepreneur I know. He says, 'There is no linear success.' So what that means is that stock chart that you just referred to, there's no up-and-to-the-right perfect chart where it's just one line.
speaker: Marc Benioff
context: Marc shares a difficult period from two years ago when Salesforce had to lay off 10% of their workforce after overhiring during the pandemic. He reflects on this failure and the broader lesson that entrepreneurship involves constant ups and downs. He quotes entrepreneur Michael Bell's wisdom that no company, not even Apple, experiences perfectly smooth growth - there will always be setbacks, economic changes, and unexpected challenges.
text_ko: 제 친구 마이클 벨은 아마 제가 아는 최고의 기업가예요. 그는 "성공에는 선형적(linear success)인 경로가 없다"고 말해요. 그러니까 방금 말씀하신 그 주식 차트(stock chart)는 한 줄로 쭉 이어져서 계속 우상향(up-and-to-the-right)만 하는 완벽한 그래프는 없다는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 我朋友迈克尔·贝尔，应该是我认识的最厉害的创业者了。他总说，"成功这事儿没有直线型的。" 意思就是你刚才提到的那个股票图表，不可能是一条完美的从左下到右上的直线，现实中根本没有这种一帆风顺的曲线。
text_es: Mi amigo Michael Bell es probablemente el mejor emprendedor que conozco. Él siempre dice: "No existe el éxito lineal". O sea, esa gráfica bursátil de la que acabas de hablar, no hay ninguna curva perfecta que vaya siempre para arriba y a la derecha, como una sola línea recta.
key_sentence: There is no linear success; no perfect up-and-to-the-right chart.
